review.title: Combining Monte-Carlo and Hyper-heuristic methods for the Multi-mode Resource-constrained Multi-project Scheduling Problem
review.abstract: Multi-mode resource and precedence-constrained project scheduling is a well-known challenging real-world optimisation problem. An important variant of the problem requires scheduling of activities for multiple projects considering availability of local and global resources while respecting a range of constraints. This problem has been addressed by a competition, and associated set of benchmark instances, as a part of the MISTA 2013 conference. A critical aspect of the benchmarks is that the primary objective is to minimise the sum of the project completion times, with the usual makespan minimisation as a secondary objective. We observe that this leads to an expected different overall structure of good solutions and discuss the effects this has on the algorithm design. This paper presents the resulting competition winning approach; it is a carefully designed hybrid of Monte-Carlo tree search, novel neighbourhood moves, memetic algorithms, and hyper-heuristic methods. The implementation is also engineered to increase the speed with which iterations are performed, and to exploit the computing power of multicore machines. The resulting information-sharing multi-component algorithm significantly outperformed the other approaches during the competition, producing the best solution for 17 out of the 20 test instances and performing the best in around 90% of all the trials.

A critical aspect of the benchmarks discussed in this paper is that the primary goal is to minimize the sum of project completion times, with the usual macespan minimization considered a secondary goal. We observe that this leads to an expected different overall structure of good solutions, and discuss the impact this has on algorithm design. This paper presents a carefully designed hybrid of Monte Carlo tree search, novel neighborhood movements, memetic algorithms, and hyper-heuristic methods. Implementation is also designed to increase the speed at which iterations are performed, and to take advantage of the computing power of multicore machines.

sections.heading: 2. Problem Description
sections.text: The problem consists of a series of projects in which each project p ² P consists of a series of activities, each not referred to as Ap. (Each project p ² P has a release time, which is the earliest start time for the activities.) The activities are linked by two different types of constraints: the priority constraints, which force each activity j ² A not to be completed earlier than all immediate precursor activities in defined red (j); and the resource constraints, in which the processing of the activities is subject to the availability of resources with limited capacity. There are three different types of resources: local renewable, local non-renewable and global renewable resources (using the superscript) have a fixed capacity per unit of time. Non-renewable resources (using the superscript) have a fixed capacity for the entire project.

sections.heading: 3. Schedule Generator
sections.text: There are two "natural" approaches in the scientific literature: a direct representation using the temporal sequence and also the nature of the activities, i.e., the earliest available time frames T and M. This is based on selecting a complete sequence of all activities. (In the face of such a sequence, a schedule is constructed by defining the activities in the order of the remaining activities and the placement of each of the earliest available time frames.) This approach is called a serial timeframe generation scheme (e.g. see [4]). The timetable-based representation is perhaps the most natural one for a mathematical programming approach, but we believe that it could make the search process for a metaheuristic method difficult, especially the creation of a feasible solution at each step could become more difficult.

sections.heading: 5. Neighbourhood Operators
sections.text: In this section, we describe our neighborhood operators, which are used by several components during the improvement phase. Operators (also referred to as low-level heuristics or simple movements, depending on the algorithm used) are divided into three groups, based mainly on the common nature of the strategy that the operators use in manipulating the solution. Some of the moves are similar to those used by other submissions; see [62], and [16] and [57] for some examples. To keep the paper self-contained, we provide brief descriptions of all the moves used in our algorithm below. We guarantee that all of our operators maintain the feasibility of the solution. Furthermore, all moves are randomized so that they can be used repeatedly for "simulated annealing" such as improvement or applied as mutation operators.

sections.heading: 5.2. Ruin & Recreate Operators
sections.text: Ruin & R operators are widely used in metaheuristics as mutations or strong local search movements, but to the best of our knowledge they are relatively new to the serial generation in planning. As the name suggests, such operators have two phases: the "Ruin" phase removes some elements of the solution and the "Create Phase" reshuffles these elements (for example, randomly) and then inserts them back again. The number of elements that are removed and reinserted is a parameter of an R & R operator that controls its strength (i.e. the average distance between the original and the resulting solution). We implement three different types of R & R operators and several strategies involved in the move. You can combine any type of R & R operator with any activity selection strategy.

sections.heading: 5.3. Project-level Operators
sections.text: The danger, however, is that the order in which the solution converges may be suboptimal. Consider two well-polished solutions S1 and S2 with different project orders; the distance between S1 and S2 is likely to be significant in terms of activity level and R & R operators, since many activities will have to be postponed in order to convert S1 to S2. Furthermore, the transitional solutions in such a conversion will be of significantly inferior quality compared to those of S1 and S2, indicating that once the algorithm is switched to a specific project order level, a lot of effort will have to be made to leave the appropriate local minimum and the project order. Project level operators are designed to overcome such barriers, allowing for a faster exploration of the rough landscape of the MRCMPSP. They are passing through at project level and thus a step by all operators from this category into a change in project order. The project we are dealing with at the level is efficient.

sections.heading: 6. Improvement Phase
sections.text: Most of the time our algorithm spends improving the initial solutions. We use a multi-thread implementation of a simple memetic algorithm with a powerful local search engine based on a hyper heuristics that controls moves described in the previous section.

[56] A recent study shows that recombination can be useful at a certain stage during the search process if the mutations do not alter the quality of the resulting individuals, leading to a population with the same fitness. sections.heading: 6.2. A Dominance based Hyper-heuristic Using an Adaptive Threshold Move Acceptance
sections.text: There is a growing interest in self-configuring, self-coordinated, adaptive, and automated search methods. Hyper-heuristics are such high-level approaches that explore the space of heuristics (i.e. move operators) rather than problem-solving solutions. [5] In the scientific literature, there are two common types of hyper-heuristics (7]: selection methods that select / mix heuristics from a set of preset low-level heuristics (which can both improve and aggravate the solution) and attempts to control these heuristics during the search process; and generation methods that aim to build new heuristics from a set of preset components. The main components of an iterative selection of hyper-heuristic methods are heuristic selection and relocation acceptance methods. At each step, an input solution is modified using a selected heuristic method.

sections.heading: 7. Experiments
sections.text: In this section, we report on the results of our computational experiments and discuss the MISTA 2013 Challenge and its results. For additional analysis of the performance of our and other submitted algorithms, see [62].

sections.heading: 7.1. Test Instances
sections.text: In our experiments, we used three sets of MRCPSP instances provided by the organizers of the MISTA 2013 Challenge. The first set (set A) was provided at the beginning of the competition, the second set (set B) was provided after the qualification phase. The third set (set X) was kept hidden from the participants of the competition until the results were announced; it was used to evaluate the performance of the submitted algorithms. During the design and tuning of our algorithm, we had no information about what properties the hidden instances would have, which drove our decisions towards self-matching methods and rich motion sequences. All three sets of instances were produced by combining PSPLIB benchmark instances [29] and can be downloaded from allserv.kahosl.be / mista2013challenge. metadata.abstractText: Multi-mode resource and precedence-constrained project scheduling is a well-known challenging real-world optimisation problem. An important variant of the problem requires scheduling of activities for multiple projects considering availability of local and global resources while respecting a range of constraints. A critical aspect of the benchmarks addressed in this paper is that the primary objective is to minimise the sum of the project completion times, with the usual makespan minimisation as a secondary objective. We observe that this leads to an expected different overall structure of good solutions and discuss the effects this has on the algorithm design. This paper presents a carefully designed hybrid of Monte-Carlo tree search, novel neighbourhood moves, memetic algorithms, and hyper-heuristic methods. The implementation is also engineered to increase the speed with which iterations are performed, and to exploit the computing power of multicore machines. Empirical evaluation shows that the resulting information-sharing multi-component algorithm significantly outperforms other solvers on a set of “hidden” instances, i.e. instances not available at the algorithm design phase.
